Howard W. Bennett, often
called the “dean” of eco¬
nomic education in Ameri¬
can industry, joined the
National Education Pro¬
gram staff as director of
field services. Shortly there¬
after he began an itinerary which will take him into
the major industries and school systems throughout
the 48 states, seeking advice for the improvement of
our educational services and offering the written and
visual aid materials being developed in our Searcy
workshops. In his 30 years with General Electric
Company, Mr. Bennett’s assignments included execu¬
tive responsibilities in the management, engineering,
manufacturing and marketing fields. During his last
10 years he spearheaded the
development of one of the
most extensive economic
education programs in
American industry, reaching
GE’s 220,000 employees and
supplying materials for sim¬
ilar programs in industries
employing several million
persons. Upon his retirement
from GE, a number of top¬
flight organizations in the East and Midwest made
attractive overtures for his services; he chose to
associate himself with the National Education Pro¬
gram (at a considerable financial sacrifice) because,
as he told Dr. Benson, “It offers the greatest oppor¬
tunity for effective work in bringing about a wide¬
spread understanding of the advantages of our
American private enterprise system.” Mr. Bennett
continues his active membership in such organizations
as the American Society of Training Directors; the
National Sales Executives Association; the U. S."
Education Institute, which at present is pioneering
classroom education through closed-circuit TV; and
others. One of his chief responsibilities in the field is
the distribution of the “American Adventure” film
series for TV and industrial employee programs.
Howprd Bennett
H Dr. Bensori’s two weekly columns—LooMmg Ahead
for newspapers, and the condensed version. Listen
Americans for industrial publications—continue to add
names to their mailing list. A recent series of columns
on the ‘'Farm Problem'’’’ emphasizing the fundamental
necessity of agricultural production for a market
economy brought in a flood of mail from farmers and
urban consumers. Ninety-eight per cent commended
Dr. Benson’s recommendation for the withdrawal of
the Federal Government from the marketing and man¬
agement and other economic functions of American
farming. More than 4,000 publications now receive
the two columns with an estimated readership of
20 million.
■ The “American Adventure” citizenship education
film series in the first six months of 1958 reached
thousands of new audiences. The total audience thus
far: 22,500,000. At latest count, nearly 1300 prints
had been purchased by organizations planning ex¬
tensive use of the films. More than half of these
sales were made to schools.
One recent purchase requisition from the State
Department of Education in Louisiana involved an
order for more than $5,560 worth of prints which
were placed in regional libraries throughout the
State for distribution to every school system in
Louisiana.
■ The National Program Letter continues to expand
its reader audience. Approximately 50,000 now go
out to influential people in the 48 states. The series
containing the dispatches of Glenn Green from Scan¬
dinavia and the Continent, reporting the facts on the
socialistic Welfare States of Europe, brought in an
unprecedented volume of reprint requests. Hundreds
of industrial employee publications published portions
of the series. The National Research Bureau, the
nation’s top producer of Reading Rack publications,
obtained permission to publish the reports in booklet
form for its industrial and organizational clientele;
there will be six Reading Rack pieces in this NRB
series with expected runs aggregating several million
copies. Our organization has been asked to follow up
this distribution with a single publication digest of
all the Welfare State material—presenting at the same
time the comparative American economic facts.

"'The afterglow of the Freedom Forum lingers with me yet. It is
more than Just an emotional experience. Ifeel that my insight has
been-so informed and my heart so moved that I will be per¬
manently affected by being aroused to responsibilities heretofore
neglected.”
J. Robert Ashcroft, President
Evangel College
Springfield, Missouri
"Attending the Freedom Forum at Harding College was a
wonderful experience, not only became of the Forum, but because
it gave me an opportunity to observe first hand the fine work
you are doing in the college there.”
D. D. Wendel, Vice President
Alabama Power Company
"I have a better concept of the menace of Socialism and a deepened
appreciation for the principles of American freedom. The contact
with other conferees has given me a broader understanding of
some of their problems.”
Mrs. Leslie Evitts
History Teacher
Fort Smith Senior High School (Ark.)
“ Whatever final impressions / record, the first is to congratulate
you and the staff on the great work being done to advance the
love of America and the American way of life. The second im¬
pression is that the great work you are doing takes great people
and there is no doubt in my mind that you and your staff are
great people.”
Bro. Stephen Sheehy
Hamilton Catholic High
Hamilton, Ohio
"It was the most informative and worthwhile meeting I have
ever been privileged to attend.”
Mrs. Carol McMullen
Reynolds Metals Company
Bauxite, Arkansas
"I have attended a number of forums, workshops, etc., but this
one was the best in organization, information given, and the
most important for our future. It was a great experience. Keep
up the great work.”
^ B. L. Wertz, Principal
. Central High School
Muskogee, Oklahoma
"This Forum has given me a purpose and objective in what will
last through life and more specifically has clarified in my mind
a previous dilemma, i.e., that labor and managements goals are
not inherently diverse, but rather that the system best for either
is best for both—the capitalistic system.”
Judge John F. Campbell
Pampa, Texas
"The wealth of information digested from the well-planned pro¬
gram, the excellent guest speakers, and the thought-provoking
questions and answers of attending conferees will help us to tell
the American Story to others.”
Robert L. Burke
Editor, HIGHLIGHTS
Houston Lighting & Power Company
"The Forum was both educational and enjoyable. I don't know of
a thing about the entire program that I could offer except praise.”
Clyde Beals, Secretary
Progress Manufacturing Co., Inc.
Arthur, Illinois
